body: Created a design doc and posted it for review at apache/accumulo-website#163

@ctubbsii. You had an interesting idea about some xml file where this may be all set up.  Like a context dependency injection type of thing like Spring. They have something like that for the Android OS but I couldn't find a java example for Linux.  I think what I checked in won't produce any runtime errors.  I did test it with Fluo-uno on my system which is running Centos-7.  We are onto a solution here but I think something more customized to our LRU caching is in order.  But that will be a vector for regression and bugs.

I don't think we should set up our own dependency injection stuff for VFS... I was mainly just wondering if VFS already supported config-only setup of this stuff, so we can just use it.

Long-term, I'd like to strip VFS out of Accumulo, and instead provide a simple entry point for user-specified (admin-specified) classloader for our existing named context classloaders. I don't think Accumulo should be in the business of maintaining custom classloaders for users inside the project... but should instead empower users to provide their own classloader from outside the project, if they so desire. Then, if they wish to use one that is based on VFS, they are free to do so, but it is their responsibility to initialize it and pass it to Accumulo.

But, that's a long-term vision, and we'd need to get there incrementally. One step could be: do less VFS setup in code, if VFS is already configurable outside of code.
I will keep looking around.

VFS has been nothing but headaches.  I would be in favor of ripping it out
completely.

Presumably, the 5-10 minutes is because each one is doing a "chop" compaction. You can speed things along by compacting the ranges ahead of time, that will be merged, and then the merge should be fast, but that doesn't save time overall. There was a feature proposal for "no-chop" merges, which would track original tablet boundaries along with file references in the metadata table, so these files wouldn't be read outside their original boundaries, and merging wouldn't need to trigger a compaction to truncate these files, but that was back-burner'd, because it was somewhat involved. It would be nice to revisit that feature for 2.1.

Presumably, the master is assigning as fast as it can, to the tservers it knows about so far. We could give the master a configurable amount of seconds to wait for tservers to start up and check in. That could let the master know about more of them before assignments begin.

I am trying to think of a good function for calculating an initial wait time.  Below is one possibility.  

```
   AT is the actual number of tablet servers
   ET is expected number of tablet servers (configurable by user?  what if AT>ET?)
   EXP is a configurable exponent 
   W is the wait time in seconds

  W = (ET - AT)^EXP / 1000
   
```

The image below is a plot of the wait times (in seconds) for 1,026 expected tablet servers with an exponent of 2.1.

![accumulo-1049](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1268739/54835300-3639ac00-4c98-11e9-9fe4-d25e7b5a3284.png)

I don't think my proposed function works well for small numbers of tablet servers.  Thinking the function should use a ratio of ET vs AT instead of the difference.  For example if I expect 10 and only 1 is online, probably want to wait longer.   The function I proposed would not do this.
Could the master simply wait for a configured % of servers to report similar to how HDFS waits for a configured % of blocks?

> Could the master simply wait for a configured % of servers to report similar to how HDFS waits for a configured % of blocks?

Yeah something along those lines would work.    Below is another version of the formula.  When the exponent is 1, its a linear ratio.

```
   AT is the actual number of tablet servers
   ET is expected number of tablet servers, configurable by user?
   OFFLINE = max(ET-AT,0)
   EXP is a configurable exponent 
   MAX is a user configurable max wait time in seconds
   W is the wait time in seconds

  W = (OFFLINE/ET)^EXP * MAX
```
This image below is for a max wait time of 1200 secs with exponents 1,1.5,2,and 3.  The Y axis is the computed wait time.  The x axis is the percent of tablet servers offline.

![accumulo-1049-3](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1268739/54841824-96cfe580-4ca6-11e9-8b47-7c7d512198bc.png)

I'm not sure this is a bug. The `accumulo.service.instance` being set in the script is associated with the default configuration for file-based logging. It's not for the metrics. The system property for metrics appears to be a similar property, but we do not try to set it for the user. The user can set this system property in their `accumulo-env.sh` script on startup, though, when they set up metrics for their system.

We could converge on the same property... but there's already a lot of assumptions being made when setting these for our scripts, that I'd be concerned that this would break somebody who managed to rely on those assumptions. In 2.0, it is my intent to argue in favor of moving more of these things under the user's control, and to have fewer assumptions in our own scripts and/or configuration about the user's intended setup. The scripts in 2.0 have already been rewritten with this principle in mind, so I'm not sure there's a lot of value in messing with the 1.9 scripts.

I'm closing this and #730 for now, but if setting this property for metrics in one's `accumulo-env.sh` script is insufficient, we can revisit this.

For mutations, we typically want to change some aspect of the key/value pair before inserting it. Not doing so would only be useful copying from one table to another.

For efficiency and atomicity of updates, we also want to batch changes to a single row into a single mutation, and not simply create a new mutation for each K/V pair.

These core concepts should be taken into account when designing any new API.

If we only produced source code, binding to the oldest supported API version would work fine... except that:

1. commons-configuration doesn't necessarily have API guarantees, if we bind to the older version, there's no guarantee it will work with the newer versions or vice-versa,
2. the newer versions [fix lots of bugs](https://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-configuration/changes-report.html#a1.10),
3. we're not just releasing the source, we're also including the commons-configuration jar in our "convenience binary" tarball assembly.

Because of 1, we have to do our due diligence to check that it will work with regardless of which we choose. Because of 2, we'd want to upgrade to ensure users aren't set up for failure, because of being forced to use an older, buggy version, because of possible incompatibilities with a newer versions. Because of 3, we have to be careful not to set users up for failure by shipping a known buggy version in our own binary assembly that they're likely to use.

All that said, I do not care if we revert #659 or apply the cast workaround to bind to the correct method. Both solutions seem to work fine. I do have a very slight preference towards keeping the commons-configuration with fewer known bugs, but I'd settle for either solution.

Also, FWIW, the incompatibility was introduced with the attempt to get Java 5 generics support in commons-configuration 1.8. Version 1.7 does not have this issue, but still fixes many bugs. We could meet in the middle on that.

Also, @keith-turner , the argument "A user can always bump their runtime version to 1.10 if we build against 1.6." applies to Hadoop also. This issue goes away entirely if a user simply drops-in the updated commons-configuration 1.10 into their Hadoop runtime installation.
